en.value: We enjoy watching old movies together.
I love cooking, but I [k]prefer[/k] eating out at the weekend.
I prefer cooking in the week.
At the weekend, I like watching movies and cooking dinner with friends.
To recap, let's take another look at the words we have just learned.
I like [k]e[/k][k]a[/k][k]t[/k][k]i[/k][k]n[/k][k]g[/k] out at the weekend.

The verb "to fancy" is used to say that you feel like doing a certain activity at a specific moment in time. 
We use this word all the time in English, so it will really come in handy in conversation!
Yeah, me too. I don't like eating out too often, though, because it's expensive. I really [k]love[/k] cooking and watching old movies! Could we cook together sometime?
Clara [k]doesn't enjoy playing|does not enjoy playing[/k] the violin.
We like watching movies on Sundays.
He likes reading in his bedroom.
Have another look at the words and question we've just seen.
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
I don't like [k]eating out[/k] at the weekend.
Select the words in the correct order.
Describing what we like doing in our free time - Verb patterns with "like, love, hate" etc.
What does Luciano fancy doing at the weekend?
I don't fancy cooking tonight. Let's go out to dinner.
Let's take a look at how to talk about some of the things we like doing.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Mike and Natalia are discussing what they like doing.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
He likes eating out in the evening.
How does Tamara feel about reading?
She doesn't fancy eating out tonight.
He [k]doesn't like playing|does not like playing[/k] the piano.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Today, I fancy cooking dinner with my family and watching a movie.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Pablo [k]doesn't like cleaning|does not like cleaning[/k].
We like eating out at the weekend.
Read and listen to the sentence.
She doesn't like reading in the evening.

When we form negatives with phrases like this, the verb "to do" changes to match the pronoun. The other verb in the sentence (the main verb) remains in its original form. Have a look at the examples below.
Fill in the gap with the correct word.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
What do you fancy doing today? Write or record your response.
He likes cooking with his partner.
What does Jenny like doing at the weekend?
I [k]don't[/k] enjoy eating out at the weekend.
Let's take a look at six verbs that help us when we talk about things we like doing.
We [k]prefer[/k] eating out at the weekend.
What does Kirsten feel like doing tonight?
When we place two verbs together, we use this structure: main verb + "-ing"

To form negatives with phrases like these, we simply add "don't" or "doesn't" before the opinion verb ("like" or "love"). Don't forget: When we form negatives with the verb "to do", we leave our main verb in its original form (meaning that we do not add an "s").
He fancies playing the piano and reading in his room.
What do you like doing at the weekend? Write or record your response.
He fancies eating out and watching old movies.
She [k]doesn't fancy cooking|does not fancy cooking[/k] tonight.
He fancies watching old movies and cooking a curry.

Did you notice? In the sentence "She likes reading.", the verbs "to like" and "to read" are next to each other. When we combine two verbs like this, we put the first verb in the present simple, and the second verb in the "-ing" form.
She likes reading before she goes to bed.
